title: Chapter 365
content:
# Chapter 365

Fists hammered into fur. Grid's knuckles connected with another rabbit's skull—a wet crunch, then silence. His chest heaved. Every muscle screamed. The wooden sword had splintered three rabbits ago, leaving him with nothing but his bare hands and the fading dregs of his stamina.

One rabbit left.

It lunged. Grid twisted, felt claws rake across his shoulder, then drove his elbow down into its spine. The creature's legs buckled. He didn't give it time to recover—grabbed it by the ears and slammed its head into the dirt. Once. Twice. The third impact left it twitching.

*Finally.*

The last rabbit's eyes rolled back, forming perfect X-shapes as it expired. Grid staggered upright, hands trembling. Something broke loose in his chest—not quite relief, not quite triumph. For over a year, these fucking rabbits had been his nightmare. Dozens of deaths. The taste of grass and blood in his mouth as he respawned, again and again, while other players asked why the hell he was dying to *rabbits*.

Black history he'd tried to bury. Now buried for real.

"Kuahahaha!"

The laugh tore out of him before he could stop it. Grid straightened immediately, adjusting his posture. *You're a Duke now. Master of Overgeared. Act like it.* He forced the laugh deeper, tried to make it sound dignified and authoritative instead of hysterical with relief.

Sticks stared at him, face twisted in confusion.

*One of the nine legends... Pagma's Descendant... is fighting rabbits?*

No. Impossible. Sticks shook his head, refusing to accept what he'd witnessed.

"Grid." He stepped forward. "Stop joking around. We need to move."

This forest felt peaceful—too peaceful. Which meant something terrible waited at its heart.

*I faced a gourmet dragon. What if Grid encounters a light dragon? A dark dragon?*

The rabbits were clearly a distraction. Grid was testing him, or warming up. Soon, the real battle would begin. The dragon battle.

Sticks opened his mouth to warn him.

A pillar of golden light crashed down from the sky, engulfing Grid where he stood over the rabbit corpse, wooden sword raised high.

Level up.

Sticks' jaw went slack. "D-Don't tell me..." His voice came out strangled. "Hunting *rabbits* was your biggest ordeal?"

The words hung in the air. Grid turned away, face hot.

"Hum hum."

He had nothing to say. No defense. Just the notification window burning in his vision.

> **[System Notification]**
> You have leveled up.

> **[System Notification]**
> You have leveled up.

> **[System Notification]**
> You have leveled up.

*Good.*

Low-level stats were fragile. Every point mattered when your foundation was this weak.

*First, bring Agility to 10.*

The rest would pile into Strength. Standard beginner distribution—maximize damage, hunt faster, level faster.

> **[System Notification]**
> **Agility** has increased by 1.

> **[System Notification]**
> **Agility** has increased by 1.

The stat points flowed into place. Grid dismissed the windows and scanned the forest.

*Next: the deer.*

Those thirsty bastards gathered at the lakeshore would be next.

He crept forward, movements careful and measured. Deer were a different beast than rabbits—literally. For a level 2 beginner, they were a genuine threat. Three times the health. Three times the attack power. Those hooves could cave in a skull.

But he wasn't some clueless newbie anymore.

*I'm a legend.*

Grid's courage swelled as he closed in on the nearest deer. He tracked its legs, watching for the telltale shift of weight before a kick. Maintained distance. Struck when it turned its head to drink.

The 30th Island—the nightmare stage that reproduced a challenger's worst trauma at 100% difficulty—

Kraugel, the 1st ranked user, had struggled here.

Grid turned it into a tutorial.

***

> **[System Notification]**
> Mission Complete.

> **[System Notification]**
> **500 Challenger Points** acquired.

> **[System Notification]**
> Your level has been restored.

The power rushed back in like a flood. Grid gasped, staggered, caught himself. His body felt incredible—light and dense at the same time, coiled with potential energy.

Level 306. Pagma's Descendant.

He flexed his fingers. Stretched out his hand and released a blade of wind with barely a thought. Jumped. The ground fell away, and he hung in the air for a heartbeat before landing in a perfect crouch.

Every muscle responded with surgical precision. Every nerve fired in perfect sync.

*This is what I've become.*

The realization hit him broadside. When was the last time he'd truly felt the difference? How much had he grown without noticing?

*I haven't been using my body properly. I need to pay more attention.*

He clenched his fist. Real-time growth. Real-time improvement.

"...Are you really Pagma's Descendant?"

Sticks' voice cut through his contemplation. The disbelief was naked in his tone.

Grid met his eyes. "I'm dull-witted," he said. No shame in it. Just fact. "Always was. Inferior to everyone around me. I've been through trials that geniuses would never experience, because I was too stupid to avoid them." His jaw tightened. "Does that disqualify me from being a legend?"

Pride burned in his chest. Not arrogance—*pride*. In himself. In what he'd overcome.

Sticks' expression shifted. He shook his head slowly. "No. That's not what I meant." A pause. "Actually... I think I respect you more now."

A dull-witted person, reborn as a legend. That took more effort than any genius could comprehend.

Grid's mouth quirked. He turned toward the gate leading to the 31st island. "Let's go."

***

> **[System Notification]**
> You have entered the 31st Island.

Sticks had never made it this far. His eyes widened as the landscape materialized around them.

"A city?"

Buildings lined the streets in neat rows—hundreds of them. Carriages clattered over cobblestones. Crowds surged through the market district. The architecture was distinctly Western, fortified and practical.

*Where is this? Why would the Hall of Fame recreate an entire city?*

"Patrian," Grid said quietly. His voice had gone flat. "The fortified city."

Sticks glanced at him. "You recognize it?"

"Lived here for a year. Level 1 to 80." Grid's jaw worked. "But I don't understand why it's here. I didn't die much in Patrian. Maybe ten times, total."

"Ten times? In a *city*?" Sticks blinked. "Did you commit crimes?"

"No." Grid's tone was defensive. "I got hit by wagons. A flowerpot fell on my head from a third-story window. Gangs of thugs would jump me in alleys."

"...Your luck is truly something else."

Before Sticks could elaborate, the system windows appeared.

> **[System Notification]**
> Your level has been reduced to **23**.

> **[Mission Details: 31st Island]**
> 
> The location and circumstances of your most-failed quest have been recreated at 100% accuracy.
> 
> Overcome your past trial. Surpass your former self.
> 
> **Clear Condition:** Complete the quest you repeatedly failed.
> 
> **First Clear Reward:** 600 Challenger Points
> 
> **First Clear Reward 2:** Original quest rewards
> 
> **Time Until Mission Start:** 30 minutes

"The quest I failed most?"

Grid frowned, rifling through memories. So many failures. Which one had he fucked up the most?

A golden exclamation point materialized above a distant building. The quest window unfurled.

> **[Quest: Participate in Reserve Forces Training]**
> 
> **Difficulty:** Regular
> 
> Patrian is a fortified city built to control the Gauss Kingdom's northern expansion.
> 
> All players residing in Patrian are required to complete monthly military training as members of the reserve forces.
> 
> Report to the training grounds and complete the required courses.
> 
> **Clear Condition:** Achieve a passing grade in all training exercises.
> 
> **Reward:** Dependent on final rank.

Grid's face went pale. "Ah. *This* quest."

Monthly. Mandatory. Inescapable. Refuse, and you'd be locked in the barracks until you complied.

*I never passed. Not once.*

How many times had he tried? Dozens? The training was designed to forge useful soldiers—practical combat drills that Patrian's military could actually deploy. The standards were high.

Too high for him.

*The training was brutal.*

Weapons proficiency. Formation drills. Squad tactics. All of it beyond his capabilities.

*There were others who failed too,* Grid reminded himself. *Hundreds of us.*

(In reality, fewer than ten. But his memory was generous to his ego.)

***

> **[Status Window]**
> 
> **Name:** Grid
> 
> **Class:** Warrior
> 
> **Level:** 23
> 
> **Health:** 1,161 | **Mana:** 45
> 
> **Strength:** 187 | **Stamina:** 40
> 
> **Agility:** 22 | **Intelligence:** 15
> 
> **Skills:**
> - Beginner Sword Mastery Lv. 2
> - Beginner Armor Mastery Lv. 2
> - Charge Lv. 1
> - Full Swing Lv. 1

Grid stared at the numbers. His eye twitched.

*This stat distribution is fucking ignorant.*

Everything dumped into **Strength**. A pitiful amount of **Stamina**. **Agility** and **Intelligence** left to rot at base Warrior values.

*No attack speed. No evasion. No mana.*

He could use **Charge** or **Full Swing** exactly once before running dry. After that? Swinging a sword like a caveman with a club.

His equipment was worse.

> **[Blunt Greatsword]**
> Attack Power: 32~71
> Attack Speed: -3%

> **[Old Skull Helmet]**
> Defense: 2

> **[Old Orc Armor]**
> Defense: 13

> **[Old Goblin Shoes]**
> Defense: 2

*Mismatched trash from different monster types.* 

Grid wanted to punch his past self in the face. No wonder he'd taken a full year to reach level 79. Not even 80. *Seventy-nine.*

*Can I even clear this quest with these stats?*

He exhaled slowly. The training would cover weapons proficiency and sparring. He could handle swords decently now—years of experience had built muscle memory. Pon had taught him spear fundamentals. But archery...

*No Bow Mastery. Base Agility. I'll be lucky to hit the target once.*

And sparring with 45 mana? He'd get one skill off before becoming a sitting duck.

Sticks was staring at him, tension radiating from every line of his body. "Is this trial truly that difficult?" His voice rose. "Don't tell me—it's a dragon, isn't it?!"

The curse had left scars.

Grid shook his head. "Relax. No dragons when you're with me."

He rolled his shoulders, loosening tight muscles. 

*Believe in yourself.*

Since becoming Pagma's Descendant, he'd faced horrors that would make normal users quit the game. Armies. Legends. Bosses designed for fifty-man raids.

Now he just had to beat his past self.

"Let's go."

Grid strode toward the training grounds, jaw set. The gate loomed ahead.

A voice barked out before he'd taken three steps inside.

"There you are, **Blue Falcon**! Late again! Hurry up, you worthless bastard! Move faster than the dog you fight like!"

Grid froze.

*Blue Falcon.*

The nickname hit him like a brick to the face—a humiliation he'd buried so deep, he'd convinced himself it never happened. His expression twisted into something demonic.

The training instructor. That old bastard who'd mocked him, degraded him, made every session a waking nightmare.

*I had no experience back then. I was helpless.*

Grid's fists clenched.

*Not anymore.*

His eyes burned as he locked onto the instructor's weathered face.

*I'm going to make you eat those words.*
